title: Couples married for five years or more could be owed £1,150 by the taxman
text:

Couples who have been married or in a civil partnership for the past five years could be owed as much as £1,150 by the taxman.

The Marriage Allowance allows non-taxpayers to transfer up to 10% of their £12,500 personal allowance to a basic rate tax-paying spouse or civil partner every year.

Those who earn between £12,500 and £50,000 and have a partner that either doesn't work or earns under £12,500 are most likely to qualify.

And doing so could leave you hundreds better off.

Transferring £1,250 to your tax-paying partner for this year will reduce your tax by £250 – and couples who haven’t claimed it for the past five years can apply for a backdated refund worth £1,150.

Figures recently released by HMRC show a steady increase in couples claiming the Marriage Allowance, which was introduced in April 2015.

In 2015/16, the first year, there were an estimated 750,000 claimants recouping £345million. In 2018/19, there were 1.78million recouping £485million.

Sean McCann, financial planner at NFU Mutual, said: “More and more people are capitalising on the Marriage Allowance but there will still be people out there unaware of this potential rebate that could be worth more than £1,000.”

This is one of a number of tax benefits available to married couples and civil partners that co-habiting couples miss out on.

Others include the ability to pass assets to each other free of inheritance tax on death, and the ability to gift assets to each other without triggering a capital gains tax charge.

Despite these benefits, the number of marriages in England & Wales has been on a steady decline since 1972, when there were 426,000 ceremonies. Latest figures show there were just 243,000 in 2016.

Meanwhile, the number of co-habiting couples has increased 25.8% in the past decade from 2.7million to 3.4million.

But by the end of the year, they'll all be able to apply for Civil Partnerships , giving an extra 3million people greater financial security.

The move, an extension of the original Civil Partnerships Act 2004, will give millions of unmarried, cohabiting couples, equal rights on savings, tax, and pensions benefits as those who wed in a traditional ceremony.

It also means they won't have to foot the £27,000 average cost of a wedding, which thousands simply cannot afford.

Under the changes, cohabiting couples who decide not to marry will be given the option to tie the knot in a speedy, paper agreement instead.

It was first announced last year under plans to equalise the law , after the Supreme Court ruled that a ban on it was in breach of the European Convention on Human Rights.
